newsitem.title: USA: Clinton asks for FCC study on curbing liquor ads.
newsitem.headline: Clinton asks for FCC study on curbing liquor ads.

text.p: President Bill Clinton on Tuesday asked the Federal Communications Commission to study ways to curb television liquor ads following the industry's decision to abandon its nearly half-century voluntary ban.

"Liquor has no business with kids, and kids should have no business with liquor. Liquor ads on television would provide a message of encouragement to drink that young people simply don't need. Nothing good can come of it," Clinton said.

Clinton, who had criticised the industry's decision last year to end the voluntary ban in effect for television since 1948 and radio since 1936, said at a White House ceremony he hoped the industry would rethink its position.
"We're here today because parents now face a new hazard in raising their childen -- the advertising of liquor on television," he said.

The distilled spirits industry has complained that there is no ban on beer and wine television advertising, but Clinton dismissed this as a rationale for liquor advertising, saying there should be no expansion of promoting the use of alcohol.
